I had dental surgery and was taking aspirin that I was prescribed. The doctors said that aspirin only rarely causes blood thinning...not that it was a characteristic of the drug. So they said I should get checked out for a common bleeding disorder. I donate platelets at the Red Cross every four weeks. Whole blood and plasma can be stored, but platelets only last five days. They are used quite a bit in cancer treatment, often a patient might need 20 units of platelets in six months. It's not pleasant, but I'm glad to help save lives.

I'll just add that aspirin isn't recommended for pain relief because of that blood-thinning side-effect.  Hospitals use acetaminophen or ibuprofen; migraine medicine often does have aspirin in it.  Also never give aspirin to a child/teen for headache or fever; if the kid has a virus, aspirin  can cause Reye Syndrome, which can be significantly brain damaging and deadly.

Aspirin is actually a nonselective COX inhibitor; it blocks both COX1 and COX2. In fact, its analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects come from COX-2 inhibition. But yeah, the effects that this video talks about comes from COX-1 inhibition.

I know you're excited about your SciShow Finds, but I've heard your pitch for it a bunch of times already, and at the start of it I immediately click away. I'm a long time SciShow viewer, starting from somewhere in 2013, but this just makes me disappointed to see content lose from self-promotion here.

I clicked on this video expecting an in-depth explanation of aspirin and its effects (seeing as it's a 4-min video, and a 4-min Vlogbrothers video can cover an entire civil war), but what I got is a short single-paragraph explaining which effect aspirin has on blood platelets (which is what you can expect from a 2-min video).

I'm just saying: please limit the promotion to something proportional to the video length, because this is just ridiculous. Besides, I can't imagine the YT algorithm liking you for short videos where a large part of the audience clicks away just after the half-way point - in fact, I can imagine the algorithm has that set as a flag for detecting clickbait (even though this video does cover what it claims in the title).

Whole blood can be separated into as many as 3 useful components, depending on the type of pack used to collect the blood: frozen products (fresh frozen plasma or cryoprecipitate), platelets, and red cells. If you have taken aspirin and donate whole blood, the nurse will still need to know when you last took aspirin in case they end up trying to use the platelets, but your donation can still be processed to make plasma products and a dose of red cells.

What's not mentioned here is that they also infuse you with a sodium-citrate solution which is itself and anti-coagulent to keep the platelets from sticking to the extraction components of the machine.
